item.description: I have mixed opinion about laptops. Being portable is fine. Small size is something you begin to appreciate over time. Ditto for power consumption. But uhhm most of laps have cr@p keyboard, 2-3 USB ports and cheap glossy TN/TFT display. So you end up with half dozen peripherals spread over the desk. That's how my setup at work looks like. At home, it's still good ol' fat desktop.

item.title: By: ThatRickGuy
item.dc:creator: ThatRickGuy
item.content:encoded:
The reason for a desktop is simple. For $1300 in your example you get a laptop that can bet used as a solid development environment.

For $700 you can have a PC with the same.

I would agree that the face of computing is changing. But I don’t see the effect nearly so significantly for those of us behind the curtains. Yeah, it’s handy to have a laptop, but at a fraction of the cost I can do the same work at my desk (which is where I’m going to be working on the laptop anyway).

item.title: By: Eli Weinstock-Herman (tarwn)
item.dc:creator: Eli Weinstock-Herman (tarwn)
item.description: I had multi-monitor on my laptop in 2008, maybe earlier. I had the laptop driving two monitors and a small tower under my desk serving up test VMs and driving a 3rd monitor. Compared to buying and supporting my own work super-tower or buying a not-so-hot one through a major manufacturer, the combination worked out pretty good at a similar price AND I could carry my main system out on the floor, to meetings, or home at night for support.

item.title: By: Doug Lane
item.dc:creator: Doug Lane
item.content:encoded:
I’d be willing to break away from desktop PCs altogether were it not for two advantages still enjoyed over laptops: ease of parts replacement and mutli-monitor support.

If my laptop mobo dies, I’m in for a lengthy and expensive replacement process (assuming it’s not cheaper to junk it). With a desktop, I order a replacement from Newegg and three days later I’m back in business. Also, desktop video cards routinely have two video out ports, whereas laptops need extra hardware (docks, dongles, etc.) to add a second monitor and the process is often cumbersome.

Until laptops can close these two gaps, I don’t think desktop PCs can die off altogether, but you’re right — their advantages versus laptops are dwindling.
